qas.question: Under what condition might the polarization of the dielectric be unable to follow the voltage?

answers.text: driven with a time-varying voltage that changes rapidly

qas.question: What type of dipoles which add to the dielectric constant cannot move instantly if a rapidly changing time varying voltage is driving the capacitor?
What is it called when a dielectric constant changes with frequency?
What is an example of a dielectric relaxation process?

plausible_answers.text: driven with a time-varying voltage that changes rapidly enough

qas.question: Under what condition might the polarization of the dielectric be able to follow the voltage?
What type of dipoles which add to the dielectric constant cannot move instantly if a slowly changing time varying voltage is driving the capacitor?
What is it called when a dielectric constant stays the same with frequency?
What is an example of an undielectric relaxation process?

context: If a capacitor is <a0_0><b5_0>driven with a time-varying voltage that changes rapidly<a0_0/> enough<b5_0/>, at some frequency the polarization of the dielectric cannot follow the voltage. As an example of the origin of this mechanism, <a1_0>the <b6_0>internal microscopic dipoles<b6_0/><a1_0/> contributing to the dielectric constant cannot move instantly, and so as frequency of an applied alternating voltage increases, the dipole response is limited and the dielectric constant diminishes. A changing dielectric constant with frequency is referred to as <a2_0><b7_0>dielectric dispersion<b7_0/><a2_0/>, and is governed by <a3_0><b8_0>dielectric relaxation processes<b8_0/><a3_0/>, such as <a4_0><b9_0>Debye relaxation<b9_0/><a4_0/>. Under transient conditions, the displacement field can be expressed as (see electric susceptibility):
